Key Arguments: The legislation threatens free speech, a fundamental component of a democratic society.
The government has previously spread misinformation, and this bill could suppress exposure of such falsehoods.
The bill represents government overreach and is inconsistent with international human rights standards.
It grants excessive power to unelected bureaucrats, lacks transparency, and accountability.
The definition of 'harm' is vague and could be used to suppress legitimate speech.
The bill does not hold digital service providers accountable for excessive policing of speech.
Government-authorized content is excluded, creating an asymmetrical standard.
The bill breaches privacy by compelling information from digital platforms.
The penalties are excessive and could chill free speech.
Notable Quotes: Free Speech is fundamental component to a democratic society and must be preserved.
The Bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The Bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats to silence speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.

The severity of the penalties for failing to comply with the misinformation codes and standards and for failing to provide evidence requested by ACMA is excessive and will provide a ‘chilling effect’ on free speech.
